title: Tax Management and Business Expenses for Gig Workers
description: Essential vocabulary and procedures for managing taxes as independent contractor

criticalVocabulary.context: Business expense that reduces taxable income
Tax payments made four times per year
Tax form showing your annual earnings from platforms
Tax form for reporting business profit or loss
Additional 15.3% tax for Social Security and Medicare
IRS allows deduction of $0.655 per mile (2023 rate)

employmentStatus.reality: You are NOT an employee of Uber, Lyft, DoorDash, etc.
implications: No taxes withheld from payments - you must pay them
Must pay both employee AND employer portion of Social Security/Medicare (15.3%)
But: Can deduct business expenses that employees cannot

taxRates.state: 0-13% depending on state (some states have no income tax)
taxRates.total: Typically 25-40% of net profit goes to taxes

quarterly Payments.requirement: Must pay estimated taxes quarterly if you owe $1,000+ annually
dueDates: Q4: January 15 of next year (September-December income)
quarterly Payments.penalty: Underpayment penalty + interest if you don't pay enough quarterly
quarterly Payments.howTo: IRS Form 1040-ES or pay online at irs.gov/payments

vehicle.twoMethods: Standard mileage rate OR actual expenses (choose most beneficial)

standardMileage.rate: $0.655 per business mile (2023 - check current year)
standardMileage.tracking: MUST track every business mile with log

actualExpenses.example: If 80% business use, deduct 80% of all vehicle expenses
actualExpenses.complexity: More tracking required but can be higher deduction

cannotDeduct: Commute from home to first ride (and last ride back home)

phone.deductible: Business use percentage of phone bill and phone purchase
phone.typical: 80-90% business use for rideshare (higher than typical job)
phone.tracking: Review phone usage; most time is for gig apps

deductible: Platform service fees (if you pay any)
Bottled water and snacks for passengers

recordKeeping.criticalRule: No documentation = no deduction. IRS requires proof

methods: Platform mileage reports (supplement only - not complete)
mileageLog.frequency: Track EVERY business trip. Recreating months later = IRS rejection

receipts.keep: All receipts for business expenses over $75. Under $75 can use credit card statement
receipts.duration: Keep for 3 years minimum (IRS can audit back 3 years, 6 if major issues)
method: Photo every receipt immediately with phone
Use Expensify, QuickBooks Self-Employed, or similar app
Store in cloud (Google Drive, Dropbox) - never lose them

incomeTracking.tips: Track cash tips separately - platforms don't report these
incomeTracking.weekly: Download weekly earnings summary from each platform as backup

calculatingNetIncome.important: This is why tracking expenses is CRITICAL. $50k gross becomes $20k take-home

timing.extension: Can file extension to October 15, but must pay estimated tax by April 15
timing.penalty: Failure to file or pay = penalties and interest

howToFile: Accountant/CPA (recommended if earnings over $50k or complex situation)

notTrackingMileage.error: Thinking platform tracking is enough (it's not - often incomplete)
notTrackingMileage.consequence: Lose thousands in deductions. Example: 25,000 miles not tracked = $16,375 lost deduction
notTrackingMileage.solution: Use Stride or Everlance from Day 1

notPayingQuarterly.error: Waiting until April to pay all taxes
notPayingQuarterly.consequence: Underpayment penalty plus huge bill you may not have saved for
notPayingQuarterly.solution: Set aside 25-30% of each payment immediately. Pay IRS quarterly

mixingPersonalBusiness.error: Not separating personal and business vehicle use
mixingPersonalBusiness.consequence: Can't claim business deductions on personal use. IRS audit risk
mixingPersonalBusiness.solution: Track every trip. If you make personal trip, note it as personal

noReceipts.consequence: IRS audit = deductions disallowed + penalties + interest
noReceipts.solution: Photo every receipt immediately. Use app to organize

wrongMethod.error: Using standard mileage when actual expenses would be better (or vice versa)
wrongMethod.solution: Calculate both methods or use tax software that compares

stateSpecifics.note: Still must pay federal and self-employment tax
stateSpecifics.additionalLocal: Some cities (NYC, San Francisco) have additional income taxes

free: IRS.gov - Free tax information and forms
VITA (Volunteer Income Tax Assistance) - Free tax prep for income under $60k
Gig worker Facebook groups for peer advice
paid: CPA specializing in self-employment ($200-500 for tax prep)
QuickBooks Self-Employed ($15/month - tracks income, expenses, mileage)
Stride Tax (free app for mileage and expense tracking)
spanish: Many VITA sites have Spanish-speaking volunteers
IRS has Spanish language forms and publications (irs.gov/spanish)

explainingToOthers.english: I'm self-employed as an independent contractor. I have to handle my own taxes and business expenses.
explainingToOthers.spanish: Soy trabajador autónomo como contratista independiente. Tengo que manejar mis propios impuestos y gastos de negocio.

askingForHelp.english: Do you know a good accountant who works with self-employed people?
askingForHelp.spanish: ¿Conoce un buen contador que trabaje con personas que trabajan por cuenta propia?

bankDiscussion.english: I need to set aside money for quarterly tax payments.
bankDiscussion.spanish: Necesito apartar dinero para pagos de impuestos trimestrales.

culturalNotes.note: US system puts all tax responsibility on you. No employer withholds or manages taxes
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: Very different from Colombian employment tax withholding system

culturalNotes.note: IRS requires extensive documentation. Verbal agreements or memory not sufficient
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: More documentation-heavy than Colombian informal economy

culturalNotes.note: IRS has significant enforcement power. Not paying taxes = serious legal consequences
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: More systematic enforcement than in many Colombian contexts

culturalNotes.note: Paying for CPA or tax software is normal and wise investment for self-employed
culturalNotes.colombianComparison: More common to use professional help than in Colombian informal economy

criticalTakeaways: Track EVERY business mile starting today - use free app like Stride
Set aside 25-30% of every payment for taxes immediately
Pay quarterly estimated taxes - don't wait until April
Calculate both standard mileage and actual expenses to see which is better
Consider QuickBooks Self-Employed or similar software ($15/month pays for itself)
Hire CPA if earnings over $50k or situation is complex
Never ignore IRS notices - respond immediately
File even if you can't pay full amount - payment plans available
Your net income (after deductions) is typically 50-60% of gross earnings
